1.question: What do we celebrate on ANZAC Day?

options.a: The landing of the first free settlers from Europe
options.b: The landing of the First Fleet at Sydney Cove
options.c: The landing of the first settlers from Asia at Gallipoli
options.d: The landing of the New Zealand and Australian Army Corps at Gallipoli

1.note: ANZAC Day is observed on 25 April each year. ANZAC Day is named after the Australian and New Zealand Army Corps, which landed at Gallipoli in Turkey during World War I on 25 April 1915.

2.question: What colours are on the Australian Aboriginal Flag?
2.note: The Australian Aboriginal Flag is black, red and yellow. The top half is black and represents the Aboriginal people of Australia. The bottom half is red and represents the earth and a spiritual relation to the land. The yellow circle represents the sun.

3.question: Which of the following is the official symbol for Commonwealth property?
3.note: The Commonwealth Coat of Arms is the official symbol of the Commonwealth of Australia. It represents our national unity. It identifies the authority and property of the Commonwealth of Australia.

4.question: The first inhabitants of Australia were:
4.note: Australia's first inhabitants were the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. They are the Indigenous people of Australia.

5.question: What is the population of Australia?
5.note: Australia has a population of about 25illion people and one of the most diverse societies in the world.

6.question: The national language of Australia is:
6.note: English is our national language. Communicating in English helps you to play a more active role inAustralian society.

7.question: The Aboriginal people of Australia were from:
7.note: Historically, Aboriginal people are from mainland Australia and Tasmania. They have lived here for between 40 000 and 60 000 years.

8.question: When did the European settlement in Australia start?
8.note: European settlement in Australia began in 1788 and we continue to welcome new migrants today.

9.question: The first governor of the New South Wales colony was:
9.note: The first governor of the colony of New South Wales was Captain Arthur Phillip. He overcame many problems in the first few years of European settlement.

10.question: Who were the early free settlers of Australia?
10.note: Early free settlers were from Great Britain and Ireland. This British and Irish heritage has had a major influence on Australia's history, culture and political institutions.

11.question: In 1851, _________ was discovered in New South Wales and Victoria?
11.note: In 1851, gold was discovered in the colonies of New South Wales and Victoria. People from all around the world came to these colonies to try their luck at making a fortune.

12.question: The colonies in Australia were officially united into the Commonwealth of Australia in:
12.note: In 1901, the colonies were united into a federation of states called the Commonwealth of Australia. At that time, Australia's population was counted at about four million people.

13.question: Why did many non-British citizens immigrate to Australia after World War II?
13.note: A wave of non-British migration came after World War II, when millions of people in Europe had to leave their homelands. Large numbers came to Australia to build a new life.

14.question: How many languages are spoken in Australia?
14.note: In Australia's diverse society, over 200 languages are spoken.

15.question: Australia is made up of:
15.note: The Commonwealth of Australia is a federation of states and territories. There are six states and two mainland territories.

16.question: Which of the following is Australia's capital city?
16.note: Canberra is Australia's capital city, and each state and mainland territory has its own capital.

17.question: Which of the following is the capital of Queensland?
17.note: Brisbane is the capital of Queensland.

18.question: Australia has ____ official flags?
18.note: The Australian National Flag is the official flag of our nation. Other flags that are officially recognised and may be flown in the community include the Australian Aboriginal Flag and the Torres Strait Islander Flag.

19.question: _________ separates Tasmania from the Australian mainland.
19.note: Tasmania is the smallest state, separated from the mainland by Bass Strait.

20.question: As an Australian citizen, it is your responsibility to:

options.a: Ensure your passport is in good condition
options.d: Defend Australia along with your fellow Australians when needed

20.note: As an Australian citizen you must: obey the law,  vote in federal and state or territory elections, and in a referendum, defend Australia should the need arise, and serve on a jury if called to do so.

21.question: ANZAC Day is celebrated on:
21.note: The anniversary of the landing on Gallipoli (25 April) is  a national holiday. It is called ANZAC Day.

22.question: Aboriginal culture is:

options.a: A new culture in both Australia and the world
options.b: The same as many other indigenous cultures
options.c: The oldest discontinued indigenous culture in the world
options.d: The oldest continuing indigenous culture in the world

22.note: Australia's first inhabitants were the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. They are the Indigenous people of Australia. Australia's Indigenous cultures are the oldest continuing cultures in the world.

23.question: Aboriginal people have been living in Australia for ____________ years.
23.note: Historically, Aboriginal people are from mainland Australia and Tasmania. They have lived here for between 40 000 and 60 000 years.

24.question: Which of the following is the capital of the Northern Territory?
24.note: Darwin is the capital city of the Northern Territory.

25.question: Australia Day is celebrated on:
25.note: On 26 January each year, we celebrate Australia Day. Australia Day is a public holiday in every state and territory in Australia.

26.question: How many states are in Australia?
26.note: The Commonwealth of Australia is a federation of states and territories. There are six states and two mainland territories.

27.question: How was Australia organized before 1901?

options.c: By 6 British colonies that governed each other

27.note: Before 1901, Australia was made up of six separate, self-governing British colonies.

28.question: The capital city of Victoria is:
28.note: Melbourne is the capital city of Victoria.

29.question: The main town near the centre of Australia is:
29.note: The Northern Territory has the tropics in the north and red desert soil in the south. Most of its small population live in the capital city, Darwin, and along the main highway between Darwin and Alice Springs, which is the main town near the centre of Australia.

30.question: What do the green strips represent on the Torres Strait Islander Flag?
30.note: The Torres Strait Islander Flag is green, blue, black and white. The green stripes represent the land. The blue panel in the centre represents the sea. The black lines represent the Torres Strait Islander people. The white dancer's headdress in the centre is a symbol for all Torres Strait Islanders.

31.question: ____ was discovered in New South Wales and Victoria in 1851.
31.note: The discovery of gold in New South Wales in early 1851 has been described as the 'discovery that changed a nation'

32.question: Australia's national flower is:
32.note: The background of the Commonwealth Coat of Arms is the golden wattle, Australia's national flower.

33.question: The first convict ships to arrive in Australia came from:
33.note: European settlement started when the first 11 convict ships, which became known as the 'First Fleet', arrived from Great Britain on 26 January 1788.

34.question: Which of the following is the second largest state in Australia?
34.note: Queensland is the second largest state. It has the Torres Strait Islands in the north, tropical rainforests, temperate coastal areas and an often dry inland.

35.question: What appears on the Australia's Coat of Arms?
35.note: The Commonwealth Coat of Arms is the official symbol of the Commonwealth of Australia. A kangaroo and an emu support the shield on each side. Kangaroos are native Australian animals and emus are native Australian birds.

36.question: __________ is the capital city of New South Wales.
36.note: Sydney is the capital city of New South Wales and is the nation's largest city.

37.question: The British Government first transported convicts to:
37.note: In 1788, Great Britain decided to send the convicts to the new colony of New South Wales.

38.question: Which of the following is Australia's largest city?
38.note: Sydney is the capital city of New South Wales and is the nation's largest city.

39.question: The Torres Strait Islands mostly lie in:
39.note: Queensland is the second largest state. It has the Torres Strait Islands in the north, tropical rainforests, temperate coastal areas and an often dry inland. T

40.question: January 26 is the anniversary of:

options.a: The discovery of diamond in Australia
options.c: The arrival in Australia of the First Fleet in 1788

40.note: European settlement started when the first 11 convict ships, which became known as the 'First Fleet', arrived from Great Britain on 26 January 1788.

41.question: The capital city of the Northern Territory is:
41.note: Darwin is the capital city of the Northern Territory.

42.question: The typical landscape in the southern part of the Northern Territory is:
42.note: The Northern Territory has the tropics in the north and red desert soil in the south.

43.question: ______________ is the capital city of Tasmania.
43.note: Hobart is the capital city of Tasmania.

44.question: British and Irish heritage has:

options.a: Had a major influence on Australia
options.d: Only influenced the government culture in Australia

44.note: Early free settlers were from Great Britain and Ireland. This British and Irish heritage has had a major influence on Australia's history, culture and political institutions.

45.question: The national police force is called the:
45.note: Australia  has a national police force called the Australian Federal Police. The Australian Federal Police investigates crimes against federal laws.

46.question: The Australian nation came about by:
46.note: Australians are proud of the fact that their nation did not emerge through revolution or bloodshed, but by negotiation and referendum.

47.question: Which of the following has its own flag?
47.note: The Australian National Flag is the official flag of our nation. Each state and territory also has its own flag.

48.question: ___________ of Western Australia's population lives in the capital city.
48.note: Western Australia is the largest state. The east of the state is mostly desert, while the south-west is a rich agricultural and wine-growing area. About three-quarters of the state's population lives in Perth, the capital city

49.question: The indigenous people of Australia share:
49.note: Indigenous people share common beliefs and traditions that still guide them today. They have a deep connection with the land that is expressed in their stories, art and dance.

50.question: What colours are on the Torres Strait Islander Flag?
50.note: The Torres Strait Islander Flag is green, blue, black and white.

51.question: The population of Australia was ____________ when the Commonwealth of Australia was officially formed.

options.a: About 4 million people plus the Indigenous people
options.b: About 4 million people including the Indigenous people
options.c: About 6 million people plus the Indigenous people
options.d: About 8 million plus the indigenous people

51.note: In 1901, the colonies were united into a federation of states called the Commonwealth of Australia. At that time, Australia's population was counted at about four million people. This number did not include the Indigenous people.

52.question: The official symbol of Australia that identifies Commonwealth property is:
52.note: The Commonwealth Coat of Arms is the official symbol of the Commonwealth of Australia. It represents our national unity. It identifies the authority and property of the Commonwealth of Australia.

53.question: What does COAG stand for?
53.note: Some responsibilities are shared between the various levels of government. The Council of Australian Government (COAG) has been set up to encourage cooperation between the levels of government.

54.question: The capital of Western Australia is:
54.note: Perth is the capital of Western Australia.

55.question: ANZAC Day is named after:

options.a: The Australian and New Zealand Army Corps
options.b: The Australian and New Zealand Cadets

55.note: ANZAC Day is observed on 25 April each year. ANZAC Day is named after the Australian and New Zealand Army Corps, which landed at Gallipoli in Turkey during World War I on 25 April 1915.

56.question: The national gemstone of Australia is:
56.note: The opal is Australia's national gemstone. In Aboriginal legend, a rainbow touched the earth and created the colours of the opal.

57.question: Which of the following is Australia's national anthem?
57.note: The colonies had developed separately, but by the late 19th century a common sense of national belonging had developed. This feeling was expressed in the words of 'Advance Australia Fair'. This song was written by Peter Dodds McCormick and first sung in Sydney in 1878. It is now our national anthem.

58.question: The population of New South Wales and Victoria in the 10 years from 1851:
58.note: In 1851, gold was discovered in the colonies of New South Wales and Victoria.  In 10 years, the population more than doubled.

59.question: Who can apply for an Australian passport?
59.note: As an Australian citizen, you have the right to apply for an Australian passport and re-enter Australia freely.

60.question: Which of the following is Australia's smallest mainland state?
60.note: Victoria is the smallest of the mainland states. Many fine buildings in Victoria were built from the wealth created by the gold rush of the 1850s.

61.question: Which of the following is Australia's largest state?
61.note: Western Australia is the largest state. The east of the state is mostly desert, while the south-west is a rich agricultural and wine-growing area.

62.question: _____ of Australians were born overseas.
62.note: Since 1945, 6.5 million people have come to Australia. Over one quarter of Australians were born overseas.

63.question: Australia was a colony of:
63.note: Australia was a colony of the Great Britain.

64.question: The capital of Queensland is:
64.note: Brisbane is the capital of Queensland.

65.question: The colour of the Australian National Flag is:
65.note: The Australian National Flag is blue, white and red.

66.question: How many official flags does Australia have?
66.note: The Australian National Flag is the official flag of our nation. Other flags that are officially recognised and may be flown in the community include the Australian Aboriginal Flag and the Torres Strait Islander Flag.

67.question: European settlement in Australia began in :
67.note: European settlement started when the first 11 convict ships, which became known as the 'First Fleet', arrived from Great Britain on 26 January 1788.

68.question: The capital of South Australia is:
68.note: Adelaide is the capital of South Australia.

69.question: What Percentage of people living in Australia were born overseas
69.note: Over one quarter of Australia's residents were born overseas, and have migrated from over 200 countries.

70.question: Which of the following statements is correct about Australia's government system?

options.a: The Queen of Australia appoints the government
options.b: The government is elected by the citizens of Australia
options.c: The Queen of Australia is elected by the government of Australia

70.note: The Australian Government is also called the Federal Government or the Commonwealth Government. It is elected by the citizens of Australia.

71.question: Which of the following demonstrates freedom of speech?

options.a: Australians are free to follow any religion
options.b: Newspapers and other media can write about any topic
options.c: Australians can choose to read any newspapers
options.d: Australians can speak in any language

71.note: Australians must respect other people's freedom of speech and freedom of expression. Newspapers, television and radio have the same freedom.

72.question: The government in Australia is:

options.b: Appointed by the Queen of Australia
options.c: Elected by the Royal family of Australia

72.note: The government in Australia is secular. This means that there is no official national religion.

73.question: Which of the following demonstrates equality in Australia?

options.a: Adults and children have the same rights
options.b: Men and women have the same rights

73.note: Men and women have equal rights in Australia. It is against the law to discriminate against a person because of their gender.

74.question: Which of the following is a responsibility for Australians 18 years old or over?
74.note: As an Australian citizen you must: obey the law,  vote in federal and state or territory elections, and in a referendum, defend Australia should the need arise, and serve on a jury if called to do so.

75.question: Which of the following is a responsibility for Australians 18 years old or over?

options.b: To serve on a jury if called to do so
options.c: To volunteer in his or her community

75.note: As an Australian citizen you must: obey the law,  vote in federal and state or territory elections, and in a referendum, defend Australia should the need arise, and serve on a jury if called to do so.

76.question: Who can apply and hold an Australian passport?
76.note: When you become an Australian citizen, you have the right to live freely in Australia.

77.question: Which of the following statement is INCORRECT?

options.a: Australians are required to follow Judaeo-Christian ethics
options.b: Australians are free  to follow any religion
options.c: Australian men and women have the same rights
options.d: Australian citizens can vote in all elections

77.note: Australia has a Judaeo-Christian heritage. However, the government in Australia is secular. This means that there is no official national religion.

78.question: Who can vote in Australia?

options.a: Citizens 16 years of age or over
options.b: Citizens 17 years of age or over
options.c: Citizens 18 years of age or over

78.note: Australian citizens aged 18 years or over must register their name and address on the electoral roll. Once you are on the electoral roll, voting is compulsory for Australian citizens aged 18 years or over in federal and state or territory elections.

79.question: Which of the following statements is correct about education in Australia?

options.a: Only men can attend university in Australia
options.b: Everyone is required to attend university in Australia
options.c: Both Australian men and women may go to university if they choose to

79.note: All Australians have the opportunity to go to university.

80.question: “Fair go” means:

options.c: One's achievements should be based on talent and effort
options.d: Australians can live in any parts of Australia

80.note: Australians do not believe in class distinctions in our society. Instead, we believe in a fair society, where everyone deserves a 'fair go'. This means that what someone achieves in life should be a result of their hard work and talents, rather than their wealth or background

81.question: Being an Australian means that you have the right to:

options.c: Live in Australia if you are in school or working

81.note: When you become an Australian citizen, you have the right to live freely in Australia.

82.question: Which of the following is correct about Defence Force in Australia?

options.a: Service in the Australian Defence Force is compulsory if you want to apply for a passport
options.b: Service in the Australian Defence Force is voluntary
options.c: Service in the Australian Defence Force is compulsory if you are not in school at the age of 18 -21
options.d: Service in the Australian Defence Force is voluntary for women

82.note: While service in the Australian Defence Force is voluntary, should the need arise it is vital that all Australian citizens be committed to joining together to defend the nation and its way of life.

83.question: Children of Australian citizens who were born outside of Australia may:

options.a: Not be recognized as Australian citizens
options.b: Be registered as Australian citizens only if they pass the citizenship test
options.c: Be registered as Australian citizens only if they study or work in Australia for 3 years or more

83.note: Australian citizens may have children born overseas. They can register their children as Australian citizens. The children then have the same rights and responsibilities of citizenship as children born in Australia.

84.question: What does equality under the law means for Australians?

options.b: Everyone earns the equal amount of money, regardless of race or ethnicity
options.c: People of other race or ethnicity should not be discriminated against
options.d: People can be treated differently depending on their race

84.note: It is against the law to try to make other people hate or act violently towards others because of their culture, ethnicity or background.

85.question: What is the consequence of not attending a polling booth to vote?

options.a: You will be sent to jail
options.b: You will have to vote twice next time
options.c: You will be fined if you do not provide a good reason

85.note: Voting is compulsory for Australian citizens aged 18 years or over in federal and state or territory elections. You will be fined if you do not provide a good reason for not voting.

86.question: Which of the following ideas demonstrates compassion for those who need help in the Australian society?
86.note: In Australia, there is a spirit of 'mateship'. This means we help and receive help from each other in times of need.

87.question: How does the government help Australians in need?

options.a: Through social security and other services
options.b: Government members donating part of their income to people in need
options.c: The Queen of Australia giving money to people in need

87.note: Our government supports Australians in need through social security and other services.

88.question: Freedom of expression means:

options.a: People have the freedom to make facial expressions
options.c: People may express their views freely through violent actions
options.d: People may express their views freely through any media

88.note: Freedom of expression allows people to express their views through art, film, music and literature.

89.question: Which of the following is true about freedom of speech in Australia?

options.a: Australians can say whatever they want, even if it damages another person's good name
options.b: Australians may swear at anyone any time
options.d: Australian citizens may not damage another person's good name

89.note: We cannot make false allegations, encourage others to break the law or damage another person's reputation. There are laws to protect a person's good name against false information.

90.question: Which of the following is correct about freedoms in Australia?

options.a: Australians are free to join any organization
options.b: Australians are free to join any legal organization
options.c: Australians are free to swear at anyone

90.note: Australians are free to join any legal organisation, such as a political party, trade union, religious, cultural or social group. People can also decide not to join.

91.question: Which of the following is true about freedom of association in Australia?

options.a: Australians cannot hold any protests against the government
options.b: Australians are required to get the approval from the Queen before holding any protests
options.c: Australians can hold protests only in poor economic times
options.d: As long as they act legally, Australians can protest against the government

91.note: Australians can gather with others to protest against a government action or an organisation. However, all protests must be within the law. This means they must be peaceful, and must not injure any person or damage property.

92.question: Which of the following is the heritage of Australia?
92.note: Australia has a Judaeo-Christian heritage, and many Australians describe themselves as Christians.

93.question: Australia is described as:
93.note: This mix of religions contributes to making Australia a vibrant multicultural society.

94.question: Which of the following have legal status in Australia?

options.a: Laws that are passed by the Australian Parliament
options.b: Laws that are passed by the Australian Queen
options.c: Laws that are passed by the citizens

94.note: Most religions have rules, but these are not laws in Australia. For example, the process of divorce, including custody of children and property settlement, must follow laws passed by the Australian Parliament. All Australians have the right to be protected by these laws.

95.question: Which of the following is true about jury service in Australia?

options.a: Serving on a jury is voluntary
options.b: Only Aboriginals can serve on a jury
options.c: Australian citizens must serve on a jury if called to do so

95.note: As an Australian citizen you must: obey the law,  vote in federal and state or territory elections, and in a referendum, defend Australia should the need arise, and serve on a jury if called to do so.

96.question: Citizens of Australia:

options.b: Do not have to join a political party
options.c: Must join a political party if they want a job in Australia
options.d: Do not have to join a political party only if they are in school

96.note: In Australia, you are free to join a political party if you choose.

97.question: Who can stand for parliament in Australia?
97.note: Men and women have equal rights in Australia. It is against the law to discriminate against a person because of their gender. Both men and women can vote and stand for parliament.

98.question: At the Australian citizenship ceremony, people pledge to:
98.note: At the citizenship ceremony, you pledge to uphold and obey the laws of Australia.

99.question: People pledge to ______________ at the Australian citizenship ceremony.

options.d: Respect the rights and liberties of all Australians

99.note: At the citizenship ceremony, you pledge that you share Australia's democratic beliefs and that you respect the rights and liberties of the people of Australia.

100.question: Which of the following statements is true?

options.a: Citizens 16 years of age or over can protest against the government
options.b: No one can protest against the government
options.d: Citizens can protest against the government, as long as they do it legally

100.note: Australians can gather with others to protest against a government action or an organisation. However, all protests must be within the law. This means they must be peaceful, and must not injure any person or damage property.

101.question: Which of the following is the official national religion of Australia?

options.d: Australia has no official national religion

101.note: The government in Australia is secular. This means that there is no official national religion.

102.question: Which of the following describes women's rights in Australia?

options.a: All Australian women must get married before the age of 35
options.b: All Australian women must get their father's permission to marry.
options.c: Australian women under the age of 20 must not get married
options.d: Australian women have the right to make their own decision about marriage

102.note: Both men and women have the right to make their own independent choices about personal matters such as marriage, and are protected by the law from intimidation or violence.

103.question: Australians are free to follow any belief of their choosing:

options.b: Only if their belief is approved by the police
options.c: Only if they do not break the law
options.d: Only if their belief is accepted by the Queen

103.note: Many people have a different cultural heritage with different beliefs and traditions. In our democratic society, we are all free to follow and share these beliefs and traditions as long as they do not break Australian laws.

104.question: Equality of opportunity in Australia means:

options.a: People should get jobs based on their skills and abilities
options.b: Men should be chosen for jobs more than women
options.c: Women should be chosen for jobs more than men

104.note: Australians do not believe in class distinctions in our society. For example, a person should get a job or a promotion on the basis of their skills, ability and experience, not because of their background.

105.question: Which of the following statements is correct?

options.a: The states  and the Northern Territory have their own police forces
options.b: The states and the Northern Territory have their own army
options.c: Only Sydney has its own police force
options.d: Territories do not have their own police forces

105.note: The states and the Northern Territory have their own police forces. They deal with crimes under state and territory laws.
